metadata.case_name: Hari alias Dada Khemu Gawali v. Deputy Commissioner of Police and State of Bombay

facts.text: Petitioner born in Bombay, resides in quarters in City of Bombay, keeps bullock carts for transport business and company for selling milk.
Prohibition Police instituted twelve prohibition cases against petitioner, all ended in discharge or acquittal.
Externment order passed against petitioner in August 1950, set aside by Government in December 1950 on appeal.
Order of detention passed against petitioner under Preventive Detention Act, 1950 in December 1953, detained in Thana District prison, moved High Court under Art 226, released before hearing.
Petitioner along with others charged with possession of liquor, case lasted two years, discharged by Presidency Magistrate on 24th February 1955 as prosecution witnesses not present.

On night of 9th October 1954, petitioner arrested with companions after midnight by Ghost Squad (special wing Crime Branch CID) for allegedly running away on sight of police van, chased and arrested, found in possession of knives and other weapons.

Notice served on petitioner in October 1954 under section 57 read with section 59 Bombay Police Act, 1951, alleging previous conviction on 14-10-1938 under sections 304/109 IPC for 6 years RI and 324/109 IPC for 2 years RI concurrently; arrests in 1948 and 1949 cases where discharged for lack of evidence; arrested 9-10-1954 with 7 others armed with weapons, suspected to commit offence under Ch XVI or XVII IPC.
Petitioner appeared before Superintendent on 8th November 1954 with counsel, filed written statement denying allegations except conviction, claimed clean life since 1938 conviction as youth.

Externment order passed by first respondent (Deputy Commissioner of Police, Crime Branch CID, Greater Bombay) on 8th November 1954 under section 57, directing petitioner to remove outside Greater Bombay for 2 years after pending case, not to enter without permission.
Petitioner appealed to Government of Bombay against externment order, appeal dismissed.
In 1938 conviction, petitioner and brother Rajaram found guilty of causing death of person who gave evidence against them.
Arrested 29-3-1948 Nagpada PS CR 273/1948 u/s 143,147,148,149,353 IPC, rioting and assault on police constable, discharged lack of evidence.
Arrested 2-5-1948 Nagpada PS CR 353 u/s 143,144,146,147,148,149,324 IPC, rioting with lathis, soda bottles, hurt to Gopal Khemu Gawli, discharged want of evidence.
Arrested 3-6-1949 Nagpada PS CR 336/1949 u/s 143,147,149,225,225B,332 IPC, rioting, assault on police officer S.K. Kothare, escape of 3 persons from custody, discharged want of evidence.

On 9-10-1954 at 12:50 am, Special Squad noticed petitioner and 7 others armed with iron bar, lathi, clasp knives, running away on seeing police van, chased and arrested; petitioner and 3 others smelling of alcohol; placed on trial under Prohibition Act and Police Act, acquitted due to discrepancies.

legal_issues.text: Whether section 57 of the Bombay Police Act, 1951 contravenes Articles 19(1)(d) and 19(1)(e) of the Constitution by imposing unreasonable restrictions on freedom of movement and residence.
Whether the externment order under section 57 is illegal as based on vague allegations and inadmissible material like discharges and acquittals.

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 57 contravenes Art 19(1)(d) and (e) by imposing unreasonable restrictions on free movement and residence; police vested with unlimited powers to extern from areas or entire state; no Advisory Board like in preventive detention; hearing and appeal illusory as police is prosecutor and judge; offences clubbed without rational connection.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 19(1)(d),(e); precedents: Chintaman Rao v. State of MP, State of Madras v. VG Row, Thakur Raghubir Singh v. Court of Wards, Dwarka Prasad v. State of UP, Ebrahim Vazir Mavat v. State of Bombay

petitioner_arguments.text: Externment order illegal, based on vague allegations, old prejudice, discharges/acquittals which are inadmissible material.

respondent_arguments.text: Petitioner has history of violence since 1948, involved in cases of assault on police, rescue from custody, recent arrest armed; previous conviction under Ch XVI IPC; satisfied likely to repeat similar offences.
Petitioner fully heard before order; materials justify subjective satisfaction.

court_reasoning.text: Section 57 is preventive measure in public interest to prevent repetition by convicted criminals; restrictions reasonable as balanced against community interest; not unlimited as local jurisdiction; no need for Advisory Board as not preventive detention; procedure under s59 provides hearing, appeal to govt, judicial review under s61; dissimilar offences clubbed by legislature wisdom; order not arbitrary, discharges can be considered for suspicion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Law based on principle that freedom of few criminals restrained for greater good of community.

court_reasoning.text: Gurbachan Singh upheld similar provision; s57 requires prior conviction, stronger basis.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Previous conviction provides solid ground for suspicion of repetition.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent: s57 unreasonable as not confined to serious offences or witness intimidation; prior conviction without time/circumstance limit irrelevant; wide powers on subjective satisfaction encroach liberty unduly.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prevention better than cure but range limited in constitutional democracy.

holdings.text: Section 57 of Bombay Police Act, 1951 imposes reasonable restrictions under Art 19(5); constitutional.
Externment order valid, not based solely on inadmissible material; discharges relevant for suspicion.
Dissenting: Section 57 unconstitutional, unreasonable restriction on Art 19(1)(d),(e).

precedents_cited.relevance: On reasonableness of restrictions under Art 19.

precedents_cited.relevance: Reasonableness depends on procedural and substantive aspects; preventive measures precautionary.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art 32 challenging vires of s57 Bombay Police Act and externment order dismissed by majority; section held constitutional as imposing reasonable restrictions; no grounds to quash order. Dissent by Jagannadhadas J holding s57 unconstitutional.

key_quotes.text: "Prevention is better than cure applies not only to individuals but also to the activities of the State in relation to the citizens of the State."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The individuals right to reside in and move freely in any part of the territory of India has to yield to the larger interest of the community."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Balances individual rights vs public interest.

key_quotes.text: "Section 57 of the Act is constitutionally invalid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
